Lit "nag Niche to debut here on April 1
By JAY GOODGOLD
In addition to the established
Collection of Words, a new literary magazine called Niche will
make its debut on the Hopkins
campus April 1.
Established by Rebecca Kay
and Dave Beaudouin, Niche will
have a similar format to Collection of Words, except that only
works from members of the
Hopkins community will be accepted.
Furthermore, the publication
will run on a "compartmental
and thematic" basis as opposed
to the generalized format of Collection of Words. The first edition will dwell on poetry. Present
plans for future issues include the
topics of fiction, drama, and one
issue dedicated to a literary figure.

According to Ellen Bernhard,
Assistant editor of Niche, the
thematic concept was formulated
to give students a forum for submitting more literary pieces.
"We would like to see the magazine as a concerted, professional
and classy publication," noted
Bernhard.
A major reason for Niche's
founding, Bernhard said was the
lack of literary magazines which
members of the Hopkins community could submit works to. Collection of Words, the sole literary
magazine on the campus, is published only twice a year, and
some of its submissions are written by people outside the
Hopkins community. Bernhard
further hopes that Niche, would
enable more Writing Seminars
students to submit their works

for publication.
"There just wasn't enough
magazine space for the material
on the campus; Collection of
Words didn't have access to many
of the people in the writing seminars program, especially those
featuring poetry and fiction,"
Bernhard said.
Niche will aceept works from
anyone who has enrolled at
Hopkins. Kay added that she has
already received pieces from
alumni for the upcoming issue.
Kay, a sophomore majoring in
Writing Seminars, hopes to have
Niche printed a couple of times.
each semester.
"I think a magazine has to
come out more than twice a year.
I spoke to Dottie Lebo [Assistant
Dean of Students] and David
Philwin, editor of Collection of

Words, and they seemed receptive to the idea of the new magazine," stated Kay.
Financial backing for Niche's
first issue is coming primarily
from the Chaplain's office. They
will supply most of the paper and
stationery supplied for the publication. The Chaplain's assistance will be given as loan.
In order to reimburse the
Chaplain's Office, Kay said, the
first publication will cost 50
cents. The proceeds from the sale
of the magazines, which Kay
hopes to be over $200, will then
go back to the Chaplain's office.
Presently, subscriptions to Niche
are being ,taken, and Kay asserted
that many people have already
ordered copies.

Lit "nag Niche to debut here on April 1
By JAY GOODGOLD
In addition to the established
Collection of Words, a new literary magazine called Niche will
make its debut on the Hopkins
campus April 1.
Established by Rebecca Kay
and Dave Beaudouin, Niche will
have a similar format to Collection of Words, except that only
works from members of the
Hopkins community will be accepted.
Furthermore, the publication
will run on a "compartmental
and thematic" basis as opposed
to the generalized format of Collection of Words. The first edition will dwell on poetry. Present
plans for future issues include the
topics of fiction, drama, and one
issue dedicated to a literary figure.

According to Ellen Bernhard,
Assistant editor of Niche, the
thematic concept was formulated
to give students a forum for submitting more literary pieces.
"We would like to see the magazine as a concerted, professional
and classy publication," noted
Bernhard.
A major reason for Niche's
founding, Bernhard said was the
lack of literary magazines which
members of the Hopkins community could submit works to. Collection of Words, the sole literary
magazine on the campus, is published only twice a year, and
some of its submissions are written by people outside the
Hopkins community. Bernhard
further hopes that Niche, would
enable more Writing Seminars
students to submit their works

for publication.
"There just wasn't enough
magazine space for the material
on the campus; Collection of
Words didn't have access to many
of the people in the writing seminars program, especially those
featuring poetry and fiction,"
Bernhard said.
Niche will aceept works from
anyone who has enrolled at
Hopkins. Kay added that she has
already received pieces from
alumni for the upcoming issue.
Kay, a sophomore majoring in
Writing Seminars, hopes to have
Niche printed a couple of times.
each semester.
"I think a magazine has to
come out more than twice a year.
I spoke to Dottie Lebo [Assistant
Dean of Students] and David
Philwin, editor of Collection of

Words, and they seemed receptive to the idea of the new magazine," stated Kay.
Financial backing for Niche's
first issue is coming primarily
from the Chaplain's office. They
will supply most of the paper and
stationery supplied for the publication. The Chaplain's assistance will be given as loan.
In order to reimburse the
Chaplain's Office, Kay said, the
first publication will cost 50
cents. The proceeds from the sale
of the magazines, which Kay
hopes to be over $200, will then
go back to the Chaplain's office.

With the three-year tenure of SC President Andy Savitz
coming to a close and three competent candidates in the
running for his position, undergraduates face a difficult decision in this week's Student Council Executive Board elections. True to Savitz's claim, the Council has reached a level
of efficiency such that students are "coming up through and
under the auspices of the SC." This situation—in addition to
making for an effective Council—insures a succession of qualified leadership.
However, while the SC has earned an unquestioned degree
of respect in the Hopkins community in the past several
years, much of the Council's unity and strength has been
dependant upon Savitz's own personal savvy and persistence.
Thus much of the Council's efficacy as a body has depended
upon the force of one of its members.
With a new President, the Council may have initial troubles
getting on its feet after such a long and imperious stewardship. However, the fresh leadership may allow for a more
open and participatory attitude in decision-making than has
existed under Savitz. The best way to launch the new Council
off to a good start is for undergraduates to vote and demonstrate their faith in the SC—whence, of course, the Council
derives most of its power.
